natural problem:
Mary chose an even $4$-digit number $n$. She wrote down all the divisors of $n$ in increasing order from left to right: $1,2,...,\dfrac{n}{2},n$. At some moment Mary wrote $323$ as a divisor of $n$. What is the smallest possible value of the next divisor written to the right of $323$?
$\textbf{(A) } 324 \qquad \textbf{(B) } 330 \qquad \textbf{(C) } 340 \qquad \textbf{(D) } 361 \qquad \textbf{(E) } 646$
natural solution: Since prime factorizing $323$ gives you $17 \cdot 19$, the desired answer needs to be a multiple of $17$ or $19$, this is because if it is not a multiple of $17$ or $19$, $n$ will be more than a $4$ digit number.

For example, if the answer were to instead be $324$, $n$ would have to be a multiple of $2^2 * 3^4 * 17 * 19$ for both $323$ and $324$ to be a valid factor, meaning $n$ would have to be at least $104652$, which is too big.

Looking at the answer choices, $\text{(A) }324$ and $\text{(B) }330$ are both not a multiple of neither 17 nor 19, $\text{(C) }340$ is divisible by $17$. $\text{(D) }361$ is divisible by $19$, and $\text{(E) }646$ is divisible by both $17$ and $19$.

Since $\boxed{340}$ is the smallest number divisible by either $17$ or $19$ it is the answer. Checking, we can see that $n$ would be $6460$, a four-digit number. Note that $n$ is also divisible by $2$, one of the listed divisors of $n$.
(If $n$ was not divisible by $2$, we would need to look for a different divisor)

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes n :: int and divisors :: "int \<Rightarrow> int set"
assumes h0 : "n > 999"
and h1 : "n < 10000"
and h2 : "even n"
and h3 : "divisors n = {d. d > 0 \<and> d \<le> n \<and> n mod d = 0}"
and h4 : "323 \<in> divisors n"
shows  "\<exists>d. d > 323 \<and> d \<in> divisors n \<and> (\<forall>e. e \<in> divisors n \<and> e > 323 \<longrightarrow> e \<ge> d)
and d = 340"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Mary chose an even $4$-digit number $n$. She wrote down all the divisors of $n$ in increasing order from left to right: $1,2,...,\dfrac{n}{2},n$. At some moment Mary wrote $323$ as a divisor of $n$. What is the smallest possible value of the next divisor written to the right of $323$?
$\textbf{(A) } 324 \qquad \textbf{(B) } 330 \qquad \textbf{(C) } 340 \qquad \textbf{(D) } 361 \qquad \textbf{(E) } 646$
 The final Answer is 340
 ### Proof
 Since prime factorizing $323$ gives you $17 \cdot 19$, the desired answer needs to be a multiple of $17$ or $19$, this is because if it is not a multiple of $17$ or $19$, $n$ will be more than a $4$ digit number.
 For example, if the answer were to instead be $324$, $n$ would have to be a multiple of $2^2 * 3^4 * 17 * 19$ for both $323$ and $324$ to be a valid factor, meaning $n$ would have to be at least $104652$, which is too big.
 Looking at the answer choices, $\text{(A) }324$ and $\text{(B) }330$ are both not a multiple of neither 17 nor 19, $\text{(C) }340$ is divisible by $17$. $\text{(D) }361$ is divisible by $19$, and $\text{(E) }646$ is divisible by both $17$ and $19$.
 Since $\boxed{340}$ is the smallest number divisible by either $17$ or $19$ it is the answer. Checking, we can see that $n$ would be $6460$, a four-digit number. Note that $n$ is also divisible by $2$, one of the listed divisors of $n$.
 (If $n$ was not divisible by $2$, we would need to look for a different divisor)
 *)

theorem
fixes n :: int and divisors :: "int \<Rightarrow> int set"
assumes h0 : "n > 999"
and h1 : "n < 10000"
and h2 : "even n"
and h3 : "divisors n = {d. d > 0 \<and> d \<le> n \<and> n mod d = 0}"
and h4 : "323 \<in> divisors n"
shows  "\<exists>d. d > 323 \<and> d \<in> divisors n \<and> (\<forall>e. e \<in> divisors n \<and> e > 323 \<longrightarrow> e \<ge> d)
and d = 340"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: Find an even number between 1000 and 10000 that is divisible by 323. What is the next smallest number that also divides it? The final answer is 340.

a_1.formal problem:
theorem
fixes n :: int and divisors :: "int set"
assumes h0 : "n mod 2 = 0"
and h1 : "n \<ge> 1000"
and h2 : "n \<le> 9999"
and h3 : "divisors = {d. d dvd n}"
and h4 : "323 \<in> divisors"
shows  "min {d \<in> divisors. d > 323} = 340"
a_1.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Mary chose an even $4$-digit number $n$. She wrote down all the divisors of $n$ in increasing order from left to right: $1,2,...,\dfrac{n}{2},n$. At some moment Mary wrote $323$ as a divisor of $n$. What is the smallest possible value of the next divisor written to the right of $323$?
$\textbf{(A) } 324 \qquad \textbf{(B) } 330 \qquad \textbf{(C) } 340 \qquad \textbf{(D) } 361 \qquad \textbf{(E) } 646$
 The final Answer is 340
 ### Proof
 Since prime factorizing $323$ gives you $17 \cdot 19$, the desired answer needs to be a multiple of $17$ or $19$, this is because if it is not a multiple of $17$ or $19$, $n$ will be more than a $4$ digit number.
 For example, if the answer were to instead be $324$, $n$ would have to be a multiple of $2^2 * 3^4 * 17 * 19$ for both $323$ and $324$ to be a valid factor, meaning $n$ would have to be at least $104652$, which is too big.
 Looking at the answer choices, $\text{(A) }324$ and $\text{(B) }330$ are both not a multiple of neither 17 nor 19, $\text{(C) }340$ is divisible by $17$. $\text{(D) }361$ is divisible by $19$, and $\text{(E) }646$ is divisible by both $17$ and $19$.
 Since $\boxed{340}$ is the smallest number divisible by either $17$ or $19$ it is the answer. Checking, we can see that $n$ would be $6460$, a four-digit number. Note that $n$ is also divisible by $2$, one of the listed divisors of $n$.
 (If $n$ was not divisible by $2$, we would need to look for a different divisor)
 *)

theorem
fixes n :: int and divisors :: "int set"
assumes h0 : "n mod 2 = 0"
and h1 : "n \<ge> 1000"
and h2 : "n \<le> 9999"
and h3 : "divisors = {d. d dvd n}"
and h4 : "323 \<in> divisors"
shows  "min {d \<in> divisors. d > 323} = 340"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_1.informal problem: Find the smallest number greater than 323 that divides a four-digit even number which is also a multiple of 323. The final answer is 340.

a_2.formal problem:
theorem
fixes n :: int and divisor :: "int \<Rightarrow> int"
assumes h0 : "even n"
and h1 : "n > 999"
and h2 : "n < 10000"
and h3 : "\<forall>k. 1 \<le> k \<and> k \<le> n \<longrightarrow> (n mod k = 0 \<longrightarrow> divisor k)"
and h4 : "divisor 323"
shows  "\<exists>k. k > 323 \<and> divisor k \<and> (\<forall>l. l > 323 \<and> l < k \<longrightarrow> \<not> divisor l) \<and> k = 340"
a_2.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Mary chose an even $4$-digit number $n$. She wrote down all the divisors of $n$ in increasing order from left to right: $1,2,...,\dfrac{n}{2},n$. At some moment Mary wrote $323$ as a divisor of $n$. What is the smallest possible value of the next divisor written to the right of $323$?
$\textbf{(A) } 324 \qquad \textbf{(B) } 330 \qquad \textbf{(C) } 340 \qquad \textbf{(D) } 361 \qquad \textbf{(E) } 646$
 The final Answer is 340
 ### Proof
 Since prime factorizing $323$ gives you $17 \cdot 19$, the desired answer needs to be a multiple of $17$ or $19$, this is because if it is not a multiple of $17$ or $19$, $n$ will be more than a $4$ digit number.
 For example, if the answer were to instead be $324$, $n$ would have to be a multiple of $2^2 * 3^4 * 17 * 19$ for both $323$ and $324$ to be a valid factor, meaning $n$ would have to be at least $104652$, which is too big.
 Looking at the answer choices, $\text{(A) }324$ and $\text{(B) }330$ are both not a multiple of neither 17 nor 19, $\text{(C) }340$ is divisible by $17$. $\text{(D) }361$ is divisible by $19$, and $\text{(E) }646$ is divisible by both $17$ and $19$.
 Since $\boxed{340}$ is the smallest number divisible by either $17$ or $19$ it is the answer. Checking, we can see that $n$ would be $6460$, a four-digit number. Note that $n$ is also divisible by $2$, one of the listed divisors of $n$.
 (If $n$ was not divisible by $2$, we would need to look for a different divisor)
 *)

theorem
fixes n :: int and divisor :: "int \<Rightarrow> int"
assumes h0 : "even n"
and h1 : "n > 999"
and h2 : "n < 10000"
and h3 : "\<forall>k. 1 \<le> k \<and> k \<le> n \<longrightarrow> (n mod k = 0 \<longrightarrow> divisor k)"
and h4 : "divisor 323"
shows  "\<exists>k. k > 323 \<and> divisor k \<and> (\<forall>l. l > 323 \<and> l < k \<longrightarrow> \<not> divisor l) \<and> k = 340"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_2.informal problem: We have an even integer $n$ between 1000 and 10000 inclusive. If $n$ is divisible by an integer $k$ between 1 and $n$, then we call $k$ a divisor of $n$. Given that 323 is a divisor of $n$, find the smallest divisor of $n$ that is greater than 323. The final answer is 340.

theorem
fixes n :: int and divisors :: "int set"
assumes h0 : "n mod 2 = 0"
and h1 : "n \<ge> 1000"

a_4.formal problem:
theorem
fixes n :: nat and divisors :: "nat list"
assumes h0 : "n > 999"
and h1 : "n < 10000"
and h2 : "even n"
and h3 : "divisors = [d. d \<leftarrow> [1..n], n mod d = 0]"
and h4 : "nth divisors (index divisors 323) = 323"
shows  "nth divisors ((index divisors 323) + 1) = 340"
a_4.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Mary chose an even $4$-digit number $n$. She wrote down all the divisors of $n$ in increasing order from left to right: $1,2,...,\dfrac{n}{2},n$. At some moment Mary wrote $323$ as a divisor of $n$. What is the smallest possible value of the next divisor written to the right of $323$?
$\textbf{(A) } 324 \qquad \textbf{(B) } 330 \qquad \textbf{(C) } 340 \qquad \textbf{(D) } 361 \qquad \textbf{(E) } 646$
 The final Answer is 340
 ### Proof
 Since prime factorizing $323$ gives you $17 \cdot 19$, the desired answer needs to be a multiple of $17$ or $19$, this is because if it is not a multiple of $17$ or $19$, $n$ will be more than a $4$ digit number.
 For example, if the answer were to instead be $324$, $n$ would have to be a multiple of $2^2 * 3^4 * 17 * 19$ for both $323$ and $324$ to be a valid factor, meaning $n$ would have to be at least $104652$, which is too big.
 Looking at the answer choices, $\text{(A) }324$ and $\text{(B) }330$ are both not a multiple of neither 17 nor 19, $\text{(C) }340$ is divisible by $17$. $\text{(D) }361$ is divisible by $19$, and $\text{(E) }646$ is divisible by both $17$ and $19$.
 Since $\boxed{340}$ is the smallest number divisible by either $17$ or $19$ it is the answer. Checking, we can see that $n$ would be $6460$, a four-digit number. Note that $n$ is also divisible by $2$, one of the listed divisors of $n$.
 (If $n$ was not divisible by $2$, we would need to look for a different divisor)
 *)

theorem
fixes n :: nat and divisors :: "nat list"
assumes h0 : "n > 999"
and h1 : "n < 10000"
and h2 : "even n"
and h3 : "divisors = [d. d \<leftarrow> [1..n], n mod d = 0]"
and h4 : "nth divisors (index divisors 323) = 323"
shows  "nth divisors ((index divisors 323) + 1) = 340"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_4.informal problem: Given a natural number $n$ that is greater than 999 and less than 10000 and is even. If the list `divisors` contains all the divisors of $n$ from 1 up to $n$ and the 324th divisor is 323, find the next divisor after 323. The final answer is 340.

a_5.formal problem:
theorem 
fixes n :: int
assumes h0 : "n mod 2 = 0"
and h1 : "n \<ge> 1000"
and h2 : "n \<le> 9999"
and h3 : "323 dvd n"
shows  "\<exists>x. x > 323 \<and> x dvd n \<and> (\<forall>y. y > 323 \<and> y < x \<longrightarrow> \<not> y dvd n) \<and> x = 340"
a_5.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Mary chose an even $4$-digit number $n$. She wrote down all the divisors of $n$ in increasing order from left to right: $1,2,...,\dfrac{n}{2},n$. At some moment Mary wrote $323$ as a divisor of $n$. What is the smallest possible value of the next divisor written to the right of $323$?
$\textbf{(A) } 324 \qquad \textbf{(B) } 330 \qquad \textbf{(C) } 340 \qquad \textbf{(D) } 361 \qquad \textbf{(E) } 646$
 The final Answer is 340
 ### Proof
 Since prime factorizing $323$ gives you $17 \cdot 19$, the desired answer needs to be a multiple of $17$ or $19$, this is because if it is not a multiple of $17$ or $19$, $n$ will be more than a $4$ digit number.
 For example, if the answer were to instead be $324$, $n$ would have to be a multiple of $2^2 * 3^4 * 17 * 19$ for both $323$ and $324$ to be a valid factor, meaning $n$ would have to be at least $104652$, which is too big.
 Looking at the answer choices, $\text{(A) }324$ and $\text{(B) }330$ are both not a multiple of neither 17 nor 19, $\text{(C) }340$ is divisible by $17$. $\text{(D) }361$ is divisible by $19$, and $\text{(E) }646$ is divisible by both $17$ and $19$.
 Since $\boxed{340}$ is the smallest number divisible by either $17$ or $19$ it is the answer. Checking, we can see that $n$ would be $6460$, a four-digit number. Note that $n$ is also divisible by $2$, one of the listed divisors of $n$.
 (If $n$ was not divisible by $2$, we would need to look for a different divisor)
 *)

theorem 
fixes n :: int
assumes h0 : "n mod 2 = 0"
and h1 : "n \<ge> 1000"
and h2 : "n \<le> 9999"
and h3 : "323 dvd n"
shows  "\<exists>x. x > 323 \<and> x dvd n \<and> (\<forall>y. y > 323 \<and> y < x \<longrightarrow> \<not> y dvd n) \<and> x = 340"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_5.informal problem: Find a number $x$ that is greater than $323$ and divides an even number $n$ that lies between $1000$ and $9999$, inclusive, and is also divisible by $323$. Moreover, $x$ is the smallest such number that no number greater than $323$ and smaller than $x$ divides $n$. The final answer is $340$.

a_6.formal problem:
Theorem
fixes n :: nat
assumes h0 : "n mod 2 = 0"
and h1 : "1000 <= n"
and h2 : "n <= 9999"
and h3 : "323 dvd n"
shows  "LEAST m. m > 323 \<and> m dvd n = 340"
a_6.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Mary chose an even $4$-digit number $n$. She wrote down all the divisors of $n$ in increasing order from left to right: $1,2,...,\dfrac{n}{2},n$. At some moment Mary wrote $323$ as a divisor of $n$. What is the smallest possible value of the next divisor written to the right of $323$?
$\textbf{(A) } 324 \qquad \textbf{(B) } 330 \qquad \textbf{(C) } 340 \qquad \textbf{(D) } 361 \qquad \textbf{(E) } 646$
 The final Answer is 340
 ### Proof
 Since prime factorizing $323$ gives you $17 \cdot 19$, the desired answer needs to be a multiple of $17$ or $19$, this is because if it is not a multiple of $17$ or $19$, $n$ will be more than a $4$ digit number.
 For example, if the answer were to instead be $324$, $n$ would have to be a multiple of $2^2 * 3^4 * 17 * 19$ for both $323$ and $324$ to be a valid factor, meaning $n$ would have to be at least $104652$, which is too big.
 Looking at the answer choices, $\text{(A) }324$ and $\text{(B) }330$ are both not a multiple of neither 17 nor 19, $\text{(C) }340$ is divisible by $17$. $\text{(D) }361$ is divisible by $19$, and $\text{(E) }646$ is divisible by both $17$ and $19$.
 Since $\boxed{340}$ is the smallest number divisible by either $17$ or $19$ it is the answer. Checking, we can see that $n$ would be $6460$, a four-digit number. Note that $n$ is also divisible by $2$, one of the listed divisors of $n$.
 (If $n$ was not divisible by $2$, we would need to look for a different divisor)
 *)

Theorem
fixes n :: nat
assumes h0 : "n mod 2 = 0"
and h1 : "1000 <= n"
and h2 : "n <= 9999"
and h3 : "323 dvd n"
shows  "LEAST m. m > 323 \<and> m dvd n = 340"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_6.informal problem: Find the smallest natural number greater than 323 that divides evenly into a number $n$ that is an even number between 1000 and 9999 and is divisible by 323. The final answer is 340.

a_7.formal problem:
theorem
fixes n :: nat and divisors :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat set"
assumes h0 : "even n"
and h1 : "n \<ge> 1000"
and h2 : "n \<le> 9999"
and h3 : "divisors n = {d. d dvd n}"
and h4 : "323 \<in> divisors n"
and h5 : "\<forall> d. d > 323 \<longrightarrow> d \<notin> divisors n"
shows  "min (divisors n - {d. d \<le> 323}) = 340"
a_7.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Mary chose an even $4$-digit number $n$. She wrote down all the divisors of $n$ in increasing order from left to right: $1,2,...,\dfrac{n}{2},n$. At some moment Mary wrote $323$ as a divisor of $n$. What is the smallest possible value of the next divisor written to the right of $323$?
$\textbf{(A) } 324 \qquad \textbf{(B) } 330 \qquad \textbf{(C) } 340 \qquad \textbf{(D) } 361 \qquad \textbf{(E) } 646$
 The final Answer is 340
 ### Proof
 Since prime factorizing $323$ gives you $17 \cdot 19$, the desired answer needs to be a multiple of $17$ or $19$, this is because if it is not a multiple of $17$ or $19$, $n$ will be more than a $4$ digit number.
 For example, if the answer were to instead be $324$, $n$ would have to be a multiple of $2^2 * 3^4 * 17 * 19$ for both $323$ and $324$ to be a valid factor, meaning $n$ would have to be at least $104652$, which is too big.
 Looking at the answer choices, $\text{(A) }324$ and $\text{(B) }330$ are both not a multiple of neither 17 nor 19, $\text{(C) }340$ is divisible by $17$. $\text{(D) }361$ is divisible by $19$, and $\text{(E) }646$ is divisible by both $17$ and $19$.
 Since $\boxed{340}$ is the smallest number divisible by either $17$ or $19$ it is the answer. Checking, we can see that $n$ would be $6460$, a four-digit number. Note that $n$ is also divisible by $2$, one of the listed divisors of $n$.
 (If $n$ was not divisible by $2$, we would need to look for a different divisor)
 *)

theorem
fixes n :: nat and divisors :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat set"
assumes h0 : "even n"
and h1 : "n \<ge> 1000"
and h2 : "n \<le> 9999"
and h3 : "divisors n = {d. d dvd n}"
and h4 : "323 \<in> divisors n"
and h5 : "\<forall> d. d > 323 \<longrightarrow> d \<notin> divisors n"
shows  "min (divisors n - {d. d \<le> 323}) = 340"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_7.informal problem: Find the smallest divisor of an even natural number $n$, where $1000 \leq n \leq 9999$, such that $n$ is divisible by $323$ and has no divisors greater than $323$. The smallest such divisor is $340$.

a_8.formal problem:
theorem
fixes n :: int and divisor_list :: "int list"
assumes h0 : "n > 999"
and h1 : "n < 10000"
and h2 : "even n"
and h3 : "divisor_list = sorted_list_of_set {d. d dvd n}"
and h4 : "nth divisor_list (find_index (\<lambda>x. x = 323) divisor_list) = 323"
shows  "nth divisor_list ((find_index (\<lambda>x. x = 323) divisor_list) + 1) = 340"
a_8.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Mary chose an even $4$-digit number $n$. She wrote down all the divisors of $n$ in increasing order from left to right: $1,2,...,\dfrac{n}{2},n$. At some moment Mary wrote $323$ as a divisor of $n$. What is the smallest possible value of the next divisor written to the right of $323$?
$\textbf{(A) } 324 \qquad \textbf{(B) } 330 \qquad \textbf{(C) } 340 \qquad \textbf{(D) } 361 \qquad \textbf{(E) } 646$
 The final Answer is 340
 ### Proof
 Since prime factorizing $323$ gives you $17 \cdot 19$, the desired answer needs to be a multiple of $17$ or $19$, this is because if it is not a multiple of $17$ or $19$, $n$ will be more than a $4$ digit number.
 For example, if the answer were to instead be $324$, $n$ would have to be a multiple of $2^2 * 3^4 * 17 * 19$ for both $323$ and $324$ to be a valid factor, meaning $n$ would have to be at least $104652$, which is too big.
 Looking at the answer choices, $\text{(A) }324$ and $\text{(B) }330$ are both not a multiple of neither 17 nor 19, $\text{(C) }340$ is divisible by $17$. $\text{(D) }361$ is divisible by $19$, and $\text{(E) }646$ is divisible by both $17$ and $19$.
 Since $\boxed{340}$ is the smallest number divisible by either $17$ or $19$ it is the answer. Checking, we can see that $n$ would be $6460$, a four-digit number. Note that $n$ is also divisible by $2$, one of the listed divisors of $n$.
 (If $n$ was not divisible by $2$, we would need to look for a different divisor)
 *)

theorem
fixes n :: int and divisor_list :: "int list"
assumes h0 : "n > 999"
and h1 : "n < 10000"
and h2 : "even n"
and h3 : "divisor_list = sorted_list_of_set {d. d dvd n}"
and h4 : "nth divisor_list (find_index (\<lambda>x. x = 323) divisor_list) = 323"
shows  "nth divisor_list ((find_index (\<lambda>x. x = 323) divisor_list) + 1) = 340"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_8.informal problem: Let's consider a four-digit even number $n$. We define a list, called divisor_list, which contains all divisors of $n$, sorted in ascending order. We know that 323 is in the list. What is the next number in the list after 323? The final answer is 340.

a_9.formal problem:
theorem
fixes n :: nat
assumes h0 : "n mod 2 = 0"
and h1 : "n \<ge> 1000"
and h2 : "n \<le> 9999"
and h3 : "323 dvd n"
shows  "\<exists> m. m > 323 \<and> m dvd n \<and> (\<forall> k. k > 323 \<and> k < m \<longrightarrow> \<not> k dvd n) \<and> m = 340"
a_9.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Mary chose an even $4$-digit number $n$. She wrote down all the divisors of $n$ in increasing order from left to right: $1,2,...,\dfrac{n}{2},n$. At some moment Mary wrote $323$ as a divisor of $n$. What is the smallest possible value of the next divisor written to the right of $323$?
$\textbf{(A) } 324 \qquad \textbf{(B) } 330 \qquad \textbf{(C) } 340 \qquad \textbf{(D) } 361 \qquad \textbf{(E) } 646$
 The final Answer is 340
 ### Proof
 Since prime factorizing $323$ gives you $17 \cdot 19$, the desired answer needs to be a multiple of $17$ or $19$, this is because if it is not a multiple of $17$ or $19$, $n$ will be more than a $4$ digit number.
 For example, if the answer were to instead be $324$, $n$ would have to be a multiple of $2^2 * 3^4 * 17 * 19$ for both $323$ and $324$ to be a valid factor, meaning $n$ would have to be at least $104652$, which is too big.
 Looking at the answer choices, $\text{(A) }324$ and $\text{(B) }330$ are both not a multiple of neither 17 nor 19, $\text{(C) }340$ is divisible by $17$. $\text{(D) }361$ is divisible by $19$, and $\text{(E) }646$ is divisible by both $17$ and $19$.
 Since $\boxed{340}$ is the smallest number divisible by either $17$ or $19$ it is the answer. Checking, we can see that $n$ would be $6460$, a four-digit number. Note that $n$ is also divisible by $2$, one of the listed divisors of $n$.
 (If $n$ was not divisible by $2$, we would need to look for a different divisor)
 *)

theorem
fixes n :: nat
assumes h0 : "n mod 2 = 0"
and h1 : "n \<ge> 1000"
and h2 : "n \<le> 9999"
and h3 : "323 dvd n"
shows  "\<exists> m. m > 323 \<and> m dvd n \<and> (\<forall> k. k > 323 \<and> k < m \<longrightarrow> \<not> k dvd n) \<and> m = 340"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_9.informal problem: Find a natural number $m$ greater than $323$ that divides an even number $n$ between $1000$ and $9999$ (inclusive), such that $323$ is a divisor of $n$, and no number greater than $323$ but less than $m$ divides $n$. The final answer is $340$.
